message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Rumor Detection on Social Media with Bi-Directional Graph Convolutional Networks
Paper Abstract: Social media has been developing rapidly in public due to its nature of spreading new information, which leads to rumors being circulated. Meanwhile, detecting rumors from such massive information in social media is becoming an arduous challenge. Therefore, some deep learning methods are applied to discover rumors through the way they spread, such as Recursive Neural Network (RvNN) and so on. However, these deep learning methods only take into account the patterns of deep propagation but ignore the structures of wide dispersion in rumor detection. Actually, propagation and dispersion are two crucial characteristics of rumors. In this paper, we propose a novel bi-directional graph model, named Bi-Directional Graph Convolutional Networks (Bi-GCN), to explore both characteristics by operating on both top-down and bottom-up propagation of rumors. It leverages a GCN with a top-down directed graph of rumor spreading to learn the patterns of rumor propagation; and a GCN with an opposite directed graph of rumor diffusion to capture the structures of rumor dispersion. Moreover, the information from source post is involved in each layer of GCN to enhance the influences from the roots of rumors. Encouraging empirical results on several benchmarks confirm the superiority of the proposed method over the state-of-the-art approaches.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs):

## Overview

Recurrent neural networks (RNNs) are designed for processing sequential data, such as text, speech, and time series, where the order of elements is important.(no content)Unlike feedforward neural networks, which process inputs independently, RNNs utilize recurrent connections, where the output of a neuron at one time step is fed back as input to the network at the next time step.

## How They Work

The fundamental building block of RNN is the recurrent unit, which maintains a hidden state—a form of memory that is updated at each time step based on the current input and the previous hidden state.(no content)This enables RNNs to capture temporal dependencies and patterns within sequences.

## Applications

RNNs have been successfully applied to tasks such as unsegmented, connected handwriting recognition, speech recognition, natural language processing, and neural machine translation.

## Key Variants

- **LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory)**: Long short-term memory (LSTM) networks were invented by Hochreiter and Schmidhuber in 1995 and set accuracy records in multiple applications domains. It became the default choice for RNN architecture.

- **Bidirectional RNNs**: Bidirectional recurrent neural networks (BRNN) use two RNNs that process the same input in opposite directions. These two are often combined, giving the bidirectional LSTM architecture.

## Historical Development

## Overview

Recurrent neural networks (RNNs) are designed for processing sequential data, such as text, speech, and time series, where the order of elements is important.(no content)Unlike feedforward neural networks, which process inputs independently, RNNs utilize recurrent connections, where the output of a neuron at one time step is fed back as input to the network at the next time step.

## How They Work

The fundamental building block of RNN is the recurrent unit, which maintains a hidden state—a form of memory that is updated at each time step based on the current input and the previous hidden state.(no content)This enables RNNs to capture temporal dependencies and patterns within sequences.

## Applications

RNNs have been successfully applied to tasks such as unsegmented, connected handwriting recognition, speech recognition, natural language processing, and neural machine translation.

## Key Variants

## Historical Development

Two early influential works were the Jordan network (1986) and the Elman network (1990), which applied RNN to study cognitive psychology.

Web search results for query: "Convolutional neural network"

Links: [{"title":"Convolutional neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convolutional_neural_network"},{"title":"Talk:Convolutional neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Convolutional_neural_network"},{"title":"Region Based Convolutional Neural Networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Region_Based_Convolutional_Neural_Networks"},{"title":"Graph neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_neural_network"},{"title":"Convolutional layer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convolutional_layer"},{"title":"Kunihiko Fukushima - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kunihiko_Fukushima"},{"title":"Neural network (machine learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_network_(machine_learning)"},{"title":"Energy-based generative neural network","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Energy-based_generative_neural_network"},{"title":"Pooling layer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pooling_layer"},{"title":"Category:Neural network architectures - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Neural_network_architectures"}]

## Convolutional Neural Network

A convolutional neural network (CNN) is a type of feedforward neural network that learns features via filter (or kernel) optimization.(no content)This type of deep learning network has been applied to process and make predictions from many different types of data including text, images and audio.

### How CNNs Work

CNNs are also known as shift invariant or space invariant artificial neural networks, based on the shared-weight architecture of the convolution kernels or filters that slide along input features and provide translation-equivariant responses known as feature maps.(no content)A convolutional neural network consists of an input layer, hidden layers and an output layer. In a convolutional neural network, the hidden layers include one or more layers that perform convolutions.(no content)As the convolution kernel slides along the input matrix for the layer, the convolution operation generates a feature map, which in turn contributes to the input of the next layer.

### Advantages Over Fully Connected Networks

CNNs use relatively little pre-processing compared to other image classification algorithms. This means that the network learns to optimize the filters (or kernels) through automated learning, whereas in traditional algorithms these filters are hand-engineered. This simplifies and automates the process, enhancing efficiency and scalability overcoming human-intervention bottlenecks.

### Historical Development

An early convolution neural network was developed by Kunihiko Fukushima in 1969.(no content)AlexNet, developed by Alex Krizhevsky et al. in 2012, was a catalytic event in modern deep learning. In that year's ImageNet competition, the AlexNet model achieved a 16% top-five error rate, significantly outperforming the next best entry, which had a 26% error rate.

## Search Results for "Deep Learning"

I've gathered comprehensive information about deep learning from the search results. Here's an overview:

### Definition and Core Concept

Deep learning refers to a class of machine learning algorithms in which a hierarchy of layers is used to transform input data into a progressively more abstract and composite representation.(no content)In machine learning, deep learning focuses on utilizing multilayered neural networks to perform tasks such as classification, regression, and representation learning.

### Key Characteristics

The adjective "deep" refers to the use of multiple layers (ranging from three to several hundred or thousands) in the network.(no content)The field takes inspiration from biological neuroscience and revolves around stacking artificial neurons into layers and "training" them to process data.

### Architectures and Applications

Some common deep learning network architectures include fully connected networks, deep belief networks, recurrent neural networks, convolutional neural networks, generative adversarial networks, transformers, and neural radiance fields.(no content)These architectures have been applied to fields including computer vision, speech recognition, natural language processing, machine translation, bioinformatics, drug design, medical image analysis, climate science, and material inspection.

### Historical Development

The term deep learning was introduced to the machine learning community by Rina Dechter in 1986, and to artificial neural networks by Igor Aizenberg and colleagues in 2000, in the context of Boolean threshold neurons.

Deep learning has become one of the most influential areas of artificial intelligence, enabling significant advances across numerous domains.

I've found comprehensive information about social media rumor detection. Here's what the search results show:

## Overview of Rumor Spread and Detection

In recent years, the rampant spread of misinformation and rumors on online social networks has raised significant concerns within the scientific and technological communities, as OSNs are powerful tools for disseminating information but can also accelerate the propagation of false or misleading content.

## Detection Approaches

One approach to detect rumors (or misinformation) is to compare the spread of a topic over social networks (such as Twitter) with those spread by reliable and authorized news agencies.(no content)The general approach by tech companies is the detection of problematic news via human fact-checking and automated artificial intelligence (machine learning, natural language processing and network analysis).

## Challenges in Detection

Researchers found that disinformation made "existing detection algorithms from traditional news media ineffective or not applicable...[because disinformation] is intentionally written to mislead readers...[and] users' social engagements with fake news produce data that is big, incomplete, unstructured, and noisy."

## Rumor Control Strategies

The rumor control process involves a first step that requires a mechanism through which trained "rumor agents" identify the most recent rumors in circulation, followed by a second step that requires a strategy for establishing the truth and/or falsehood of the rumors.(no content)The density and rate of forwarding of a message could be observed to detect patterns of activity that suggest the use of bots and fake account activity in disinformation attacks.

Links: [{"title":"Talk:Graph neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Graph_neural_network"},{"title":"Graph neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_neural_network"},{"title":"Network neuroscience - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_neuroscience"},{"title":"GNN - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GNN"},{"title":"Recursive neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recursive_neural_network"},{"title":"Topological deep learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topological_deep_learning"},{"title":"Small-world network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Small-world_network"},{"title":"Theano (software) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theano_(software)"},{"title":"Forward algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forward_algorithm"},{"title":"Multimodal representation learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multimodal_representation_learning"}]

## Graph Neural Networks (GNN)

Graph neural networks (GNN) are specialized artificial neural networks that are designed for tasks whose inputs are graphs.

### Key Characteristics

Several GNN architectures have been proposed, which implement different flavors of message passing, started by recursive or convolutional constructive approaches.(no content)As of 2022, it is an open question whether it is possible to define GNN architectures "going beyond" message passing, or instead every GNN can be built on message passing over suitably defined graphs.

### Capabilities and Limitations

GNNs cannot be more expressive than the Weisfeiler–Leman Graph Isomorphism Test. In practice, this means that there exist different graph structures (e.g., molecules with the same atoms but different bonds) that cannot be distinguished by GNNs.

### Applications

GNNs have diverse real-world applications:

- **Drug Design**: Molecular drug design is a prominent example, where each input sample is a graph representation of a molecule, with atoms forming the nodes and chemical bonds between atoms.

- **Protein Folding**: Graph neural networks are one of the main building blocks of AlphaFold, an artificial intelligence program developed by Google's DeepMind for solving the protein folding problem in biology.

- **Social Networks and Recommendations**: Social networks are a major application domain for GNNs due to their natural representation as social graphs. GNNs are used to develop recommender systems based on both social relations and item relations.

- **Optimization and Computing**: GNNs are used as fundamental building blocks for several combinatorial optimization algorithms. Examples include computing shortest paths or Eulerian circuits for a given graph.

- **Natural Language Processing**: Graph-based representation of text helps to capture deeper semantic relationships between words. Many studies have used graph networks to enhance performance in various text processing tasks such as text classification, question answering, and Neural Machine Translation.

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about Graph Convolutional Networks:

## Overview

The graph convolutional network (GCN) was first introduced by Thomas Kipf and Max Welling in 2017.(no content)GCNs can be understood as a generalization of convolutional neural networks to graph-structured data.

## How GCNs Work

A GCN layer defines a first-order approximation of a localized spectral filter on graphs.(no content)The key design element of GNNs is the use of pairwise message passing, such that graph nodes iteratively update their representations by exchanging information with their neighbors.

## Applications

Graph neural networks (GNN) are specialized artificial neural networks that are designed for tasks whose inputs are graphs. One prominent example is molecular drug design. Each input sample is a graph representation of a molecule, where atoms form the nodes and chemical bonds between atoms form the edges.

## Broader Context

Other "flavours" of MPNN have been developed in the literature, such as graph convolutional networks and graph attention networks, whose definitions can be expressed in terms of the MPNN formalism.

GCNs represent an important advancement in deep learning, enabling neural networks to effectively process and learn from graph-structured data, which has applications far beyond just molecular analysis.

I've performed a web search for "Social media" and found comprehensive information about the topic. Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Social media is used to share memories, form friendships, build communities and learn.(no content)These interactive platforms allow individuals, communities, businesses, and organizations to share, co-create, discuss, participate in, and modify user-generated or self-curated content.

## Popular Platforms

Popular social media platforms with over 100 million registered users include Twitter, Facebook, WeChat, ShareChat, Instagram, Pinterest, QZone, Weibo, VK, Tumblr, Baidu Tieba, Threads and LinkedIn.(no content)Other popular platforms that are sometimes referred to as social media services include YouTube, Letterboxd, QQ, Quora, Telegram, WhatsApp, Signal, LINE, Snapchat, Viber, Reddit, Discord, and TikTok.

## Growth and Usage

As of 2023, as many as 4.76 billion people used social media some 59% of the global population.

## Definition

Social media marketing is the use of social media platforms and websites to promote a product or service.(no content)The term social media was first used in 2004 and is often used to describe social networking services.

## Impacts

Social media has both positive and negative impacts. Social media has been criticized for a range of negative impacts on children and teenagers, including exposure to inappropriate content, exploitation by adults, sleep problems, attention problems, feelings of exclusion, and various mental health maladies.

Web search results for query: "Recursive neural network"

Links: [{"title":"Recursive neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recursive_neural_network"},{"title":"Recurrent neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recurrent_neural_network"},{"title":"RNN - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RNN"},{"title":"File:Simple recursive neural network.svg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Simple_recursive_neural_network.svg"},{"title":"Neural network (machine learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_network_(machine_learning)"},{"title":"Long short-term memory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Long_short-term_memory"},{"title":"Graph neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_neural_network"},{"title":"Attention (machine learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attention_(machine_learning)"},{"title":"Category:Neural network architectures - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Neural_network_architectures"},{"title":"Bidirectional recurrent neural networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bidirectional_recurrent_neural_networks"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about recursive neural networks:

## Definition

A recursive neural network is a kind of deep neural network created by applying the same set of weights recursively over a structured input, to produce a structured prediction over variable-size input structures, or a scalar prediction on it, by traversing a given structure in topological order.

## Key Differences from Recurrent Neural Networks

It's important to note that recursive neural networks are distinct from recurrent neural networks. Whereas recursive neural networks operate on any hierarchical structure, combining child representations into parent representations, recurrent neural networks operate on the linear progression of time, combining the previous time step and a hidden representation into the representation for the current time step.

## Variants and Approaches

Recursive neural tensor networks use a single tensor-based composition function for all nodes in the tree. Additionally, an efficient approach to implement recursive neural networks is given by the Tree Echo State Network within the reservoir computing paradigm.

## Training

The gradient is computed using backpropagation through structure (BPTS), a variant of backpropagation through time used for recurrent neural networks.

## Applications

Recursive neural networks have been applied to natural language processing.(no content)Extensions to graphs include graph neural network (GNN), Neural Network for Graphs (NN4G), and more recently convolutional neural networks for graphs.

Links: [{"title":"Rumor spread in social network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rumor_spread_in_social_network"},{"title":"Social media - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_media"},{"title":"Rumor control center - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rumor_control_center"},{"title":"Rumor - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rumor"},{"title":"Gossip protocol - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gossip_protocol"},{"title":"Misinformation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Misinformation"},{"title":"Rumor Scanner Bangladesh - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rumor_Scanner_Bangladesh"},{"title":"Social network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_social_networks"},{"title":"Fake news - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fake_news"},{"title":"Gossip - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gossip"}]

I've found comprehensive information about rumor spread in social networks. Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Process

A rumor is an unverified piece of information circulating among people, especially without solid evidence, and in the social sciences involves a form of statement whose truthfulness or honesty is not quickly or ever confirmed.

## How Rumors Spread in Networks

Rumors spread through a population by categorizing people into three groups: ignorants (susceptible to the rumor), spreaders (actively spreading it), and stiflers (who have heard it but lost interest in spreading it). When spreaders meet ignorants, they attempt to "infect" the other individual, converting ignorants to spreaders. When spreaders meet people who already know the rumor, those involved may turn into stiflers.

## Network Structure Impact

In small-world networks—where the shortest path between two randomly chosen nodes is much smaller than expected—rumors can spread far away with clear phase-transition patterns.

## Modern Challenges

In recent years, the rampant spread of misinformation and rumors on online social networks (OSNs) has raised significant concerns, with several models proposed to analyze and control rumor spread in OSNs.(no content)Social media makes it easier for rumors to spread and more difficult for rumor control to be managed, and by 2018, "rumor cascades" were under investigation as stories with serious inaccuracies were spread by millions of people.

When spreaders meet ignorants, they attempt to "infect" the other individual, converting ignorants to spreaders. When spreaders meet people who already know the rumor, those involved may turn into stiflers.

## Network Structure Impact

In small-world networks—where the shortest path between two randomly chosen nodes is much smaller than expected—rumors can spread far away with clear phase-transition patterns.

## Modern Challenges

In recent years, the rampant spread of misinformation and rumors on online social networks (OSNs) has raised significant concerns, with several models proposed to analyze and control rumor spread in OSNs.(no content)Social media makes it easier for rumors to spread and more difficult for rumor control to be managed, and by 2018, "rumor cascades" were under investigation as stories with serious inaccuracies were spread by millions of people.

message_text:
Excellent! I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Rumor Detection on Social Media with Bi-Directional Graph Convolutional Networks". Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Type:** Contribution (the paper proposes a novel method)

**Entities Extracted and Validated:** 7 triples

### Key Findings:

1. **Social media** (concept) - The domain where rumors spread and need to be detected
2. **Rumor spread in social network** (task) - The core problem being addressed
3. **Graph neural network** (method) - Foundation for the proposed approach
4. **Convolutional neural network** (method) - Basis for GCN layers used in the model
5. **Deep learning** (method) - The overall approach used for automatic pattern learning
6. **Recursive neural network** (method) - A prior method that the paper improves upon
7. **Bi-Directional Graph Convolutional Networks** (method, **novel**) - The main contribution proposed by the paper

All triples have been validated with correct Wikipedia URLs and relevance descriptions. The validation confirmed:
- At least 1 "uses" relation (actually 6)
- At least 1 "proposes" relation (1 novel method proposed)
- All URLs are valid and point to English Wikipedia articles

Sources:
- [Graph neural network](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_neural_network)
- [Deep learning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_learning)
- [Convolutional neural network](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convolutional_neural_network)
- [Recurrent neural network](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recurrent_neural_network)
- [Recursive neural network](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recursive_neural_network)
- [Social media](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_media)
- [Rumor spread in social network](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rumor_spread_in_social_network)
